column11: Rohit Sood,Raghav Syal,Pankaj Makkar,Neha Singhal,Keshav Bagri,Naman Wadhva,Akshay Chiripal
column17:
Series B Strategy
- $5-20M tickets (typical $12-15M) in 5-6 deals a year
- valuation $30-200M
- would like to own 10-15% and be the lead
- Large tech-first companies with playbooks built (city expansion, etc willing to take leadership risk)

Series A Strategy
- $2-5M typical ticket (coinvest with Blume, Matrix, Sequoia)
- with ROFR to lead the B

Round is defined on the concept of risk not capital need
Fund economics work on the concept of 10x return to exit. With dilution this usually becomes 6x.
AVOID: product risk, bad founder, bad founder relationships
TAKE: once PMF done, Unit Economics not favorable, business model risk, competition, macro risk and execution risk.
focus: health, fintech, commerce/logistics, space, future of work, circular economy.


$500M deployable capital over the next 4 years

Earlier fund Series B&C ($8-10M in $30-100M valuation)
Owns Penguin Random House, etc and Udacity -- large global publisher.  US focused (strategic) to add value to Bertlesmann and India fund where the parent is the original VC. Originally growth fund (Series B, C)

Broadly 4-5 deals in the range of $10M a year.

$500 M - Series A-D - India Focused launched in Jun 22 (fintrackr)

column17:
* BTV is Fintech only fund; first fund BTV-I was $75m (big hits - Unit; BTV II $125m + $75m opportunity; has hit $140m
  * His solo fund 500 FinTech before BTV-I which was $15m fund is 8x MOIC he said - biggies were Albert, Chipper, Bloom Credit)
* BTV I - Unit (Banking as a Service), Coast, Super.mx are blowout hits he said
  * $1-3m seed for 10-15%; seed sizes have supersized he said - not easy he said to get stakes.
* BTV II - raised $140m. All existing LPs reupped. He said they pushed for 2+20 => after 3X it is 25% with full catch up. He said they got lots of push back on this clause, but every fund 1 LP committed to fund 2 anyway, so he thinks they are getting through. Interesting how he is able to push this through…maybe with oru FundII performance, we can push for Fund V with similar.
* Tiger came in 4 of his companies - he said the same thing as I said - they come in at A and give money but no help, so BTV has to continue managing! Big issue. He complained to Scott. He said Scott is a good friend and had dinner at his $140m house.
* Everett Randle’s article on Tiger is the single best PR for Tiger Global per Scott. That one article repositioned Tiger as a legit operator in the minds of the Valley folks and not an undersized Softbank per Scott. People understood that Tiger is a serious operator and is playing per a strategy. Sheel ran into Everett Randle in Scott’s house (they all are in Miami / Florida anyway)

column11: David Rossow,Antonio Garcia-Maldonaldo,Chris Chen,Archana Srivatsan,Hari Menon,Kiran Anthony
column17:
CVC of the foundation, $50B endowment. 

$2.5B evergreen fund, 90 investments across debt, equity, etc
Used to do Fund Investments in the past -- staying away now. Investments have to have a very clear purpose. Had a poor experience with funds.

Financial inclusion, Healthcare and Delivery models in sub-saharan Africa and India 

$10-20M Series B prefer to have someone else lead. Alongside investments come a set of charitable commitments and targets companies should focus on.

Filter: "What can this company do to achieve our goals"
- build product 
- achieve this scale

Team of 12 people (10 of Seattle and 2 from London).

* Healthcare/Agri Company/Life Sciences: Care about upstream and downstream tech eg BioNTech
- upstream increasing yield and crop protection (eg Cropin In India)
- downsteam eg 1mg, Heledoc (Indo telemedicine app), Stellapps
- primary healthcare through digital and physical models to low income people.
* Delivery Side: models that are in-country and have alignment with endowment strategies (eg Bikash Bangladesh, Kaleidofin, Avanti in India and sub-saharan Africa) for digital use cases of credit and savings for target beneficiaries.

column17:
- Strategic investment arm of Singapore govt. (GIC and Temasek are primarily financial investors, and also invest into funds)
- Diverse global coverage with investments in USA, Europe, China, India, Southeast Asia. Occasionally invest in funds for geographical expansion or other potential opportunities.
- Sectors: Enterprise SaaS (largest team), Healthcare (med-tech, digital health, biotech, etc.), Emerging Tech (future of mobility themes)
- Stage & Cheques: Primarily focus on growth-stage (Series B to pre-IPO), with $5-15 mn cheques as both lead and as co/follow-on investors (given smaller cheques). Also brought in an early-stage team last year (sector agnostic, like serial entrepreneurs & experienced founders wanting to domicile in Singapore, $0.5-1 mn cheques)
- Given strategic objective, will only invest in companies with some expansion plans into Singapore (i.e. some presence via partial operations, team, local talent leveraging, etc.). Not a necessary condition upfront, but need a line-of-sight for this objective.

- 1st fund. INR 1,000 cr fund, 400 cr to deploy in 2024.
- $10-20 mn cheques across 10 cos
- Mid-market PE. Likes cos with 200+ cr topline, profitable (or near), 2-3yr IPO timeline.
-Not keen on lending (esp. unsecured), deep tech, binary outcomes like digital gaming, or capex/asset-heavy models. Flexible on stake, board seat.

column17:
Singapore based, control oriented, mid market, growth investor.
- Can't do minority deals in general; LP pitch is for 51% and above. This can be achieved by cleaning out messy cap tables. >50% makes it easy for them in general to take things ahead.
- EBITDA losses are OK but need a high-margin stack
- TAM needs to be large enough
- Ticket size is $50-100M range, preferred $60-75M. Will add $30-40M more over time.

Generally, valuation sensitive/margin of safety. Was getting ed-tech assets at 4-5x ARR when the leaders were at 10x ARR

column17:
- 125 investments with $200M deployed in 2021
- 60% in Japan, 40% outside of it but with more of a focus on South Asia as opposed to SE Asia

Several Key corporates are LPs but at the same time they also manage around 10-12 CVCs on behalf of these corporates

### Investment Style

- Invest in Pre-Series A and above but Series A is the sweet spot - **$1-$4M is the typical ticket size but this depends on if deployment coming from CVC or flagship fund.**
    - However one of their funds is a growth fund - this is a rarity that they’ll engage on a C+ levels
- Technical expertise is a key value proposition for GB
- Range very varied - $100-$200k to $2-$3m sweet spot and even up $5m given sufficient conviction

column17:
Hummingbird is a global, industry-agnostic, early-stage venture firm that invests from pre-seed to Series B. The firm is a low-frequency, high conviction investor that works with the most ambitious entrepreneurs — the portfolio of led deals includes Kraken ($10bn valuation), Deliveroo ($7bn valuation), Peak Games ($2bn exit), Pristyn Care, Khatabook, Jupiter, and inVideo. 

LPs are only entrepreneurs, former-entrepreneurs, high net worth individuals e.g. founder of Deliveroo, Booking.com, Elasticsearch giving Hummingbird a fund duration of up to 14 years rather than the average of 7 (no need to force exits etc.) Hummingbird makes 3-5 investments a year on average which is much less than the industry average, but have always doubled/tripled down on those investments - up to $35M per portfolio company.

Several thesis-specific vehicles, including:
1. Pre-IPO Funds: INR 2000 cr fund I, fully deployed & in exits mode. Raising Fund II now, based in GIFT.
2. Healthcare PE: 2nd fund currently deploying. Like early-stage health-tech & life sciences businesses with a strong IP driver.
3. Proprietary book (Balance sheet) investments: Alignment with Kotak's key businesses, so mainly BFSI cos
4. Special Situations Fund: Mix of debt (19% IRR) and equity. $20-30m cheques will be too small for them (re Slice)
5. Infra fund: Keen on EV themes currently
6. Buyout fund: Raising now

column17:
* Left Lane was spun out of Insight Partners by some folks including Vinny (who in his Insight avatar had picked Chargebee as one of his bets which has done v well since) 
* Arjun has been travelling a lot more to India and is the guy who does the ground work / recce etc 
* Vinny came earlier this year for the first time since the pandemic (recently became a dad in 2022) 
* They will do early ($5 mill) to late ($60 mill) 
* In India, however, they seem to be more focussed on entering at valuations in the $50-$250 mill range - very rarely will they go beyond that in either direction 
* They want to be concentrated in portfolio, 15-20 positions and close to the founders / company 
* Don't expect to do more than 2 a year in India (so, v selective, like most overseas players - lots of noise, v little action / closure) 
* Only 2 India investments, made recently - Astrotalk and a SaaS play ($5-6mill rev, NCR based, AI applied to photos / sold to photographers - mostly bootstrapped / profitable)

column6: Software & Technology,Consumer,Edtech & Upskilling,Impact/ESG,BFSI & Fintech,Healthcare & Lifesciences,EV & Mobility
column17:
A. Equity Proposition
- MUFG & Liquidity Group-backed $500mn Singapore-based Mars Dragon Fund.
- Growth-stage, Series C+, <10% stake, $25-100m cheques. No local investment restrictions here. Can do secondaries also.
- Targeting 10 investments in India & SE Asia
- Valuations typically $300+ mn. Can do primary+secondary mix of max 60-40 ratio
- Prefer companies having ARR of atleast $10-15+ mn for software and $20-25+ mn for consumer.
- 5-7 year exit horizon; Can hold or invest further in public markets as well.

B. Private Credit Proposition: 
- $1 bn AUM, $700m under the Unicorn fund
- $25-100m cheques. Can go to $5-10m for exceptional cases, such as a fast-growing SaaS
- Largely sector agnostic, except crypto and gambling businesses (figuring out for lending businesses)
- Prefer being the sole lender. For >$100m deals, okay with bringing on more lenders.
- Preference for cross-border lending (vs on-ground) in USD currency to offshore entities. No direct lending to Indian entities (since no INR currency & don't want to compete with local market), but okay to figure out structured lending at group-level to offshore entities in USD (e.g. business in US but entity in India - Can figure out case-by-case).  
- Lending for growth/acquisition/refinancing only, not runway extension. Need 15-20m of existing runway.

column17:
Radical Ventures, a $550 million AI-focused fund based in Toronto. The team includes Parasvil Patel, an HBS and IIT Bombay alumnus, who can be contacted at parasvil@radical.vc. The fund concentrates on AI and data-driven ventures, targeting solutions for the West and US corporations. They invest in both software and hardware, with sectors including climate, robotics, agri, and niche AI applications. Their typical investment size ranges from $1 million to $15 million, with a sweet spot of $5 million to $15 million. To date, they have made one investment in India - Pixxel. They do not have a specific India mandate.

Concentrated, long-term focus, growth inv strategy.

Our Life Sciences Pulse strategy: therapeutics, diagnostics, and life sciences tools, $25-40M
Global Innovation strategy: mid to late- stage tech bs with the potential to become large public cos., $50-100M (cloud, data & AI, Internet & ecomm, fintech).
6 inv criteria:
1. Sustainable above-average earnings growth
2. Leadership position in a promising business space
3. Significant competitive advantages/unique business franchise
4. Clear mission and value-added focus
5. Financial strength
6. Rational valuation relative to the market and business prospects
Seeking 3M+ in sales, usually come in at B

column17:
Global background:
- Different funds for different geographies (India, China, US, SE Asia, etc.)
- US fund began in 2006 - Focus only on growth investments (key invt. - HighRadius)
- China fund: Does seed to Series A stage. 150+ cos. (key invt - TikTok, largest shareholder). Operations are strained currently as capital is flowing from the US and there are restrictions on China investments.

India Background:
- Started in 2019. AIF investments, not SIG BS.
- Series A and onwards, including follow-ons
- Typically $6-8 mn Series A, $12-15 mn Series B, thereon undetermined. Can also do small upto $1 mn, and as high as $30-40 mn. Long-term holding period, as single org. capital.
- Bhavani leads India practice. Earlier Bhavani and Sai ? team expanded to 5 people all based in BLR now.
- Sectors of interest: Somewhat agnostic, but like technology, venture business without tech are a hard-sell internally. Need a strong tech backbone. Sector-agnostic, but dislike lending businesses unless its' a software play (e.g. 42 Cards, Lentra).

- Sai: Fintech, Agritech, Crypto, Web3, 
- Shishir/Aastha: Healthtech, Edtech
- Abhilash/Aastha: Consumer internet & B2Bx

Portfolio of 28 companies, all in the US and now venturing outside of the US. Sid is the first employee outside the Bay area.

Would like to collab on thesis areas in Healthtech.

predominantly seed and series A.

Russian fund backed by Interros group with $1.5B AUM. Acquired by UAE's Rockstone Ventures in 2023.

column17:
CVC team for Yara International ASA (a world leading crop nutrition and agriculture company headquartered in Norway).
Focus on two industries: agriculture and clean hydrogen.

For startups: Typically $3mn for the initial investment; stage agnostic. Prefer to be the lead investors but are happy to follow.
For funds: Typically $3mn. Majority in agriculture (not interested in consumer food). like to co-invest on deals in sweet-spot and share dealflow (both ways).
